nodes.bodyText:
There's no need to document these it in a javadoc comment, a normal comment will suffice.
The reasons can get stale. The interested reader can presumable try removing the suppressions and see what warnings they get and why.
since we should always delete these it's better to remove from both branches and put it immediately after it's creation.
Why does the withKeySerializerConfig() class take a String if it could take a Class?
If you're going to the trouble of abstracting an interface it's probably worth documenting the semantics of these methods.

withKeyDeSerializerConfig → withKeyDeserializerConfig
Also if everything is just going to use StringDeserializer why not make that the default so you only need to call the method if you're using a different Deserializer?
You could make the method take org.apache.kafka.common.security.auth.SecurityProtocol for better type safety, if you don't mind the dependency leaking to your clients.
Similarly you could use org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.OffsetResetStrategy

Something is wrong if you're implementing an interface with all methods throwing UnsupportedOperationException. I'm guessing you've had to do this because you wanted a different builder for the tracing case? I think you need to question why your builder has to be an inner class of some AbstractKafkaClient subclass.
